news politics priti-patel-set-oversee-more-"RNLI release footage of migrant rescue mission in JulyByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Priti Patel is set to oversee more small-boat Channel crossings than there are voters in her constituency, Labour has said.Labour Analysis found thatthe number of people crossing the Channel remains consistent with this year, the total would be more than , next year. Thataposs more than the number of electors in the Home Secretaryaposs constituency of Witham, which has , voters. The partyaposs number-crunching showed a % increase in the number of people crossing the channel over the last year. Each year since , the number of migrants making the perilous crossing across the Channel in small boats has multiplied. From  in , to , in , to , in  and more than , have arrived this year, almost triple last year’s tally. Labour’s Shadow Home Secretary, Nick Thomas Symonds MP, condemned the Home Secretary and the Prime Minister’s silence on the English Channel crossings as “inexcusable and reckless.” And branded the Home Secretary’s failure to prevent the huge numbers risking their lives to cross the English Channel as a “dangerous and le threatening situation” for those making the journey as well as a “broken promise to the British people”.  Boris Johnson has ordered a cross-government review into the migrant crisis as he is exasperated by a failure to stem the number of crossings from France, The Times reported on Saturday.But Mr Thomas-Symonds called on the PM to go further, and agree to a Channel crossings taskforce to meet weekly until the crisis is under control. He demanded on Ms Patel formally begin negotiations on new asylum regulations, publishing plans and timescales for the negotiation– with clear deadlines to prevent yet another winter of record channel crossings. And he said Ministers must prioritise the creation of properly managed safe and legal routes to help to prevent people from using people-trafficking routes and risking their lives on the English Channel – including the reintroduction of the Dubs Scheme for unaccompanied children. Mr Thomas-Symonds told the Mirror: “More and more people are risking their lives in the world’s most dangerous sea lanes in the English Channel. “After promising to address this, the Home Secretary has been completely absent and has lost control. In her two years as Home Secretary, far from the situation improving, we’ve seen an unprecedented % increase in numbers making the journey. “The Home Secretary has not only failed to end the dangerous and le threatening situation on the channel but also broken her promise to the British people to sort out the crisis on our borders. “It’s clear that the Home Secretary cannot be trusted in this issue and that urgent action is needed.”  Ms Patel has blamed the EUaposs open borders - established by the Schengen Agreement - for failing to check the movement of people through the bloc. Speaking to reporters during a visit to Washington, she said she was constantly pressing the French on the issue but that they were overwhelmed. Letaposs not forget that the real problem on illegal migration flows is the EU has no border protections whatsoever - Schengen open borders, she was quoted as saying. More than , people have arrived in the UK so far this year after making the Channel crossing in small boats - almost three times the number there were in . This includes at least , who arrived since Monday, according to data compiled by the PA news agency. This number is set to rise as the exact figure for Tuesday is still being finalised by the Home Office. It is thought at least  migrants have died in the last few weeks while trying to make the dangerous crossing. It comes as campaigners threatened the Home Secretary with legal action over so-called pushbacks after reports she had sanctioned the tactics to turn migrants around back towards France at sea. Meanwhile, French President Emmanuel Macron is reported to have said the British oscillate between partnership and provocation when discussing the migrant crisis in an interview with Lille-based newspaper la Voix du Nord, adding: We need to further strengthen collaboration. Officials have described how violence levelled at French police has intensied recently, highlighting incidents where an officer had their ear bitten off, and another where cannisters of CS gas had to be used to disperse a group of migrants. Sir Keir linked the increase to Government cuts in Britainaposs foreign aid budget as well as its failure to get a better agreement with France.We have not had strong enough agreements with France on this and we havenapost done the work upstream, he told the BBC Radio  Today programme.One of the reasons many Tory MPs were unhappy with the Government for cutting its foreign aid budget is because they knew that budget is used, in part, to deal with some of the problems that are driving the movement of people. You will never solve the immediate problemyou donapost solve the upstream problem. The Home Secretary repeatedly says in strong language what she is going to do about the immediate problem and delivers absolutely nothing. You have got to do the work upstream otherwise you will never solve this problem. Downing Street said the Government was continuing to work extremely closely with the French authorities on the issue, but that the problem required a co-ordinated response from countries across Europe. We are facing a global migration crisis choreographed by organised crime groups who put people on these boats to make these incredibly dangerous crossings, a No  spokesman said. This is an urgent issue for the whole of Europe, requiring incredibly close working together with our neighbours - France, Belgium and the Netherlands - as well as our friends across the continent. It is a shared problem so we need shared solutions. Sir Keir said the Government also had only itself to blame for the failings in Britainaposs busted asylum system. Ms Patel complained earlier this week that a dysal system had allowed Liverpool bomber Emad Al Swealmeen to remain in the UK despite reportedly having had an asylum application rejected in . Sir Keir said: My jaw dropped when I heard the Home Secretary say that the problem is that the asylum system is busted. This Government has been in power for  years. If the asylum system is busted it is busted under their watch. Asylum applications used to be dealt with in about six months many years ago. It now takes years. All of us MPs have constituents who have been waiting two years or more for their case even to be looked at. Sothe asylum system is busted the question is who busted it and the answer is the Government. been forced to issue a joint statement with her top official after she was plunged into a furious briefing war with her own staff. She is said to have considered drafting a letter to the Cabinet Secretary lambasting her civil servantsapos progress on the issue. But it was reportedly never sent - and the civil servants then got wind of the letter and hit back. One told the newspaper: “She comes into meetings and her suggestions are erratic and outlandish. “Officials come out of the meetings and the texts start flying, describing her as a moron and an idiot”.” Another said: “Whataposs become clear is that she [the Home Secretary] is out for herself and only interested in how this plays out publicly.  “If we worked collaboratively then we could get things done but instead we just have cloud cuckoo land public statements.” And one said bluntly: “She hates us and we all hate her.”It comes after a bullying probe found Ms Patel broke the Ministerial Code, only for Boris Johnson to over-rule it and say she did not.The Home Office reached a settlement in March with Philip Rutnam, the former permanent secretary who resigned accusing Ms Patel of a “vicious and orchestrated briefing campaign”.  Last night Sir Philip’s replacement, Matthew Rycroft, issued a joint statement with Ms Patel attempting to quell the row. It said: “The Home Office is responsible for delivering some of this Government’s biggest priorities – recruiting , police officers and cutting crime, keeping our country safe from terrorism, and implementing the New Plan for Immigration. “We are both hugely grateful for the hard work of the thousands of public servants who work to do this every single day. “While personal and anonymous attacks are regrettable and a very unfortunate part of public le, as joint leaders of the Home Office we will not let them distract from building a department able to rise to the challenges of today and tomorrow.”It came as a Cabinet ally, Sajid Javid, insisted Covid had made it more dficult to send failed asylum seekers back to the countries from which they came.Shadow home secretary Nick Thomas-Symonds said on Sunday that at the current rate, more migrants will be travelling to Britain via the English Channel that there are voters in the Home Secretaryaposs constituencythe Government doesnapost act. And hundreds more people, including very young children, have made the dangerous Channel crossing to the UK over the weekend. Adults carrying youngsters and others wrapped in blankets were seen arriving on the south-east coast of England on Saturday with help from leboat crews, before winter fully sets in. And while official figures have not been confirmed it is believed hundreds of people made the journey. More than , people have arrived in the UK so far this year after making the Channel crossing in small boats - almost three times the number there were in . Polling for the Sundaysuggested % of the public and % of voters who backed the Tories at the last election believe the Governmentaposs approach to managing Channel crossings is too soft. Mr Thomas-Symonds accused Home Secretary Priti Patel of comprehensively failing to deal with the problem. He said: “Her incompetence on this issue is dangerous”. Blasting her for attempting to blame civil servants he said: “With this Home Secretary it’s always somebody ’s fault rather than taking responsibility for her own decisions.” The Home Office declined to add to the joint statement. title: sajid javid plays down need
story: Sajid Javid plays down need to move to Plan B in wake of Covid surge in EuropeThe Health Secretary insisted he was not ­complacent about numbers as experts claim the UK is unlikely to experience a surge similar to the rest of Europe but urged people to remain cautious in the run-up to ChristmasThe Health Secretary played down needing to move to Plan B as cases surge in Europe Image: REX ShutterstockByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov | commentsThe Health Secretary has played down any need to move to Plan B to tackle Covid in the wake of the surge of cases in Europe. Sajid Javid insisted it was not yet time for more restrictions to be introduced but he urged people to remain cautious in the run-up to Christmas.He said: “If we needed to take further measures with Plan B then we would do so, but we’re not at that point.” Mr Sajid insisted he was not ­complacent about numbers as experts claim the UK is unlikely to experience a surge similar to the rest of Europe.Booster vaccine doses will be available on the NHS for people most at risk from Covid who have had a second dose of a vaccine at least  months ago.From today,  to  year olds are able to book booster jabs as well  to -year-olds their second doses.  Mr Javid suggested he would extend boosters to healthy under-srecommended by the JCVI watchdog, which is reviewing the issue. Vaccines chiefs are also said to be considering dosing children aged between five and  next spring.Prime Minister Boris Johnson has refused to rule out imposing his Plan B with mandatory masks and vaccine passports as a “blizzard” of cases hits Continental hotspots.One of the creators of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine predicted Covid rates are “unlikely” to surge in the UK this winter as in Europe because we’re already suffering so badly. Prof Sir Andrew Pollard said the UK is less likely to see the “very sharp rise” being recorded in other European countries. UK cases of the Delta iant are already high and have been since summer, with more than , people dying per week. Some experts fear vulnerable patients may have died because they did not get a third jab when the Government promised. Sir Andrew warned Covid will be with us “for the decades ahead”, with cases in the UK up .% in a week.  His comments about rates could ease fears of a lockdown in the UK after restrictions in Austria and the Netherlands led to protests. Sir John Bell of the Vaccine Task Force said “my bet at the moment” is the UK would not see as powerful a surge as parts of Europe. He said: “My advice is, order that turkey, because it’ll all be fine. sAndyou’re planning a skiing holiday in Austria, things may not go so well.” The expert added: “In many ways the pattern of our disease doesn’t match the pattern of the European disease. “You’ll remember way back in the dark days of March, April, May , everybody said, ‘Oh gosh, aren’t the Germans clever, they haven’t got any Covid and aren’t the Brits dumb because they’ve got lots of it’. I don’t think it has quite played out that way.” Mr Javid did not rule out adding European hotspots to the travel red list, saying: “We keep our travel rules with respect to the virus under review all the time.” But he said mandatory vaccination is not something the Government would “ever look at” bringing in – apart from NHS and social care staff. Mr Javid admitted the Government is not on track to meet its promise of , more GPs because of the focus on the pandemic. He said: “Let’s wait and see where we eventually get to.” Comment MORE ON NHSBoris JohnsonPoliticsCoronavirusSajid Javid MP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. A leaked dossier has laid bare plans to axe the shambolic system in . But a major step in winding it down will come next week. The Sunday Mirror understands the contact tracing system run by Sitel and Serco will be wound up early over crippling costs. Up to , contact tracers and call handlers were last week told their jobs were being axed, insiders said. In briefings by managers, teams were told there was “no money left”. Changes to the way tracing is done and more use of technology means jobs will be lost. And although Serco refused to comment, sources say they will not renew their contract when it expires on November . The Government’s plan is contained in a -page Whitehall dossier codenamed Operation Rampdown.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The document details how Test and Trace will be ditched and the requirement for those exposed to Covid to self-isolate for  days will end. It comes despite the UK recording more than , new Covid cases on consecutive days last week. With a deadly fourth Covid wave sweeping Europe, experts fear the Government has made the wrong choice. Independent Sage’s Professor Susan Michie, a behavioural scientist, warned: “If we want to avoid the kind of lockdowns we are seeing in mainland Europe we need to step up our efforts in managing the pandemic and not start shutting them down. “The World Health Organisation says a working test, trace and isolate system is a cornerstone of pandemic management. Unfortunately the model which the Government pursued has been eye-wateringly expensive and not as effective as it should have been. “The model is broken, the model was never the correct one... and it has been evident all along.  “Transmission rates are still high – there are more than , new cases a day and , deaths a week. It is not a situation a country like ours should be accepting or happy to live with.” Currently, those who self-isolate are supposed to be contacted by Test and Trace workers to check they are complying with the rules. Unvaccinated travellers who arrive in the UK may also no longer be contacted. A White hall insider said: “The trough has run dry and the Treasury isn’t prepared to keep feeding the beast. The problem is, however, that cases are still re and winter is yet to begin. “For all its faults, it’s a dangerous game to sack contact tracers when the pandemic is still raging. You only have to look to Europe to see how things change. This is going to cause problems tracking iants or even keeping an eye on local outbreaks.” Test and Trace was set up in May  with a £billion budget.This year the programme – heralded as “world-beating” by PM Boris Johnson – received another £billion. The total is equivalent to a fth of the entire annual NHS budget.The Tories were slated for outsourcing Test and Trace, with , consultants paid a typical £, per day.  Covid call centres, meanwhile, were staffed by minimum-wage workers on two-week rolling contracts. All NHS Test and Trace Covid testing sites in England began closing at pm from this month in a bid to start saving cash. But Covid cases have doubled four times since June. And the Independent Sage  warned that “a further doubling would put tremendous pressure on our health service”. The system has also come under fire from education bosses. Last week it emerged that the Government had been unable to say how many contacts of Covid cases have been traced in schools since the start of the new academic year. This comes as latest figures show that Covid cases are rising once again among pupils, amid warnings from heads about the importance of contact tracing. The Department of Health and Social Care said it did not have data on the number of people who had been identied and contacted as Covid contacts in a school. The UK Health Security Agency said: “ Contact tracing remains a vital part of reducing Covid- transmission and therefore of our current NHS Test  Trace service. “If you are told to isolate by NHS Test  Trace it is essential that you do, unless exempt. We are constantly looking to make the tracing service as responsive, efficient and effective as possible.” Comment MORE ON Boris JohnsonNHSThe TreasuryWorld Health OrganisationPoliticsCoronavirusSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Exclusive: Tory MPs including Sajid Javid cashing in from links to private health firmsEXCLUSIVE: Health Secretary Sajid Javid holds share options in a Calornia tech firm that provides articial intelligence software to the health sector, which Labour calls a “clear conflict of interest and breach of the ministerial code”Sajid Javid is one of the Tory MPs who benefits from links to private health firms Image: Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA dozen Tory MPs including Health Secretary Sajid Javid benefit from links to private health firms, we can reveal.Our investigation comes as a bill is debated today which campaigners warn will further entrench private healthcare in the NHS.The MPs with links to private health and science firms will all get to vote on the bill in Parliament.It comes as Boris Johnson ’s Government is the focus of fury over sleaze allegations linked to MPs with lucrative second jobs. Mr Javid holds share options in a Calornia tech firm that provides articial intelligence software to the health sector, which Labour calls a “clear conflict of interest and breach of the ministerial code”.Mr Javid reported that the options in C.ai to be worth around £, and he is said to have started the process of selling them.Do you have a story  Email webnews@mirror. A Department of Health and Social Care spokeswoman said: “The Secretary of State has acted in line with the ministerial code and has properly declared these share options in the usual way.” Doctor Care Anywhere, a private  for GP appointments, paid for MP Paul Scully MP’s £, hospitality ticket to see an England v India cricket match at Lord’s.  Serco, which was involved in the part-privatised NHS Test and Trace system in England, paid for the office space of MP Ranil Jayawardena in Hampshire constituency valued at almost £, a year. Pharmaceutical wholesaler Sigma pays former health minister Steve Brine £, a year for up to eight hours’ work a month as a “strategic adviser”. title: we need leader who shows
story: We need a leader who shows us the right thing to do and instead we have Boris JohnsonA new study this week showed wearing a mask reduces incidences of Covid by %. So it’s the right thing to do for all of us. But especially the right thing to do for the Prime Minister.Boris Johnson has been slammed for failing to wear a mask on public transport - which is against Government guidanceopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Nov | commentsThe Prime Minister said: “People have actually seen me wearing face coverings quite a bit more regularly as we have seen the numbers ticking up in the UK. “I think that is the responsible thing to do and I am going to continue to do it.” Great quote. Great sentiment. Responsible leadership at last. That was only a few days ago. But guess what happened next  That’s right. Mr Johnson was snapped on a northern train – more of this in a second – maskless. Bare-faced. Unfettered. It’s impossible to keep track of how many times our Prime Minister says something then does something . This pandemic is still raging. Cases are high. Winter is coming. We need to be on our guard. We need a leader we can look towards who shows us the right thing to do. Instead, we have Boris Johnson. Of course wearing a mask is not ideal. It’s not pleasant. It’s hot and stuffy and a nuisance. But it’s the right thing to do. You don’t have to wear one on every form of public transport – it’s not a legal requirement. But it’s the right thing to do. You know what the single most effective public health measure against the virus is  Go on, have a guess. Masks. A new study this week showed wearing a mask reduces incidences of Covid by %. So it’s the right thing to do for all of us. But especially the right thing to do for the Prime Minister. It just keeps happening. Even his apology this week sounded insincere – the giggling of a naughty schoolboy rather than a man who admits he’s wrong and vows to do better. He’d been caught without a mask at a hospital in the North East, not too far from where his friend went for an eye test. Mr Johnson said: “As for not wearing a mask in Hexham Hospital, which you wrap up into my general litany of crime, can I just say...” It’s not a serious remark. But this is not a serious man. For Mr Johnson to be caught out again is not really a surprise. But probably the most frustrating, exhausting, disappointing thing about this latest effort is where it took place. A train. A train in the north of England. A train running on a network that Mr Johnson and his Government promised to upgrade. We told you weeks ago he wasn’t going to do it, that he would let down the north and go back on his word. Sometimes, it is horrible being right. At least one good thing about this is that it means another blow to Mr Johnson’s credibility. His approval ratings are beginning to slide, the poll lead is shaky, and an election not the foregone conclusion it once was. Mr Johnson’s true character is emerging, revealing a lightweight figure not up to the task. The good times are over and the mask, as it were, has finally slipped. title: we should grateful mps give
story: We should be grateful MPs give up  minutes a year to ensure poor stay happyWe all know Members of Parliament find it hard to get by on a measly £, a year - no wonder they all want second jobs to keep them goingGeoffrey Cox Image: AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByMark Steel:,  Nov | commentsAt last it seems that some politicians feel a tinge of regret for spending their time on other jobs to bring in extra money, rather than concentrating on their main one. So Geoffrey Cox will make a heartfelt apology to the law firm that pays him over £, an hour – for nipping off to do  minutes a year in his second job as an MP. The MP Julian Smith will declare: “It has been a deep honour to earn £, for a few hours work advising energy companies. I am deeply sorry that I neglected my duties to them, by popping off occasionally to earn extra cash by moonlighting as an MP.” Some Tory MPs suggested it can be “really grim” to live on the MPs’ salary of £,. This is why they’re forced into taking second jobs. So I’m sure they’d approve of a change in the law, so anyone earning £, or less would be allowed to work somewhere  while still being paid for the first job that they don’t turn up to.  If you work in Morrisons, you’ll be allowed to spend all week advising an investment bank, then nip to the checkout for  minutes a month to charge someone for three tins of baked beans. Then you can put in for a few thousand pounds’ worth of expenses, for essential items such as a flamingo cleaner and a submarine. Tory MP Andrew Rosindell insisted we should be “cautious” before criticising MPs who can’t live on £, as we shouldn’t expect them to change their lestyle and remember that they’re human beings. He was just as sensitive when he supported cutting Universal Credit, saying claimants often “didn’t need the money, they just like the extra £”. It’s touching how he wants to also protect the lestyle of people with no money. If they clean offices all day for £ an hour, then take their kids to a foodbank, an extra £ would disrupt that lestyle. So Andrew goes out of his way to safeguard it, because he cares. There have been suggestions that working mothers who need more money should take on second jobs. They could grab a colander and stand at the end of a sewage pipe catching the turds before they float into the sea. Or they could charge £ a day to be a bouncy castle for Jacob Rees-Mogg’s children at a birthday party. Environment Secretary George Eustice actually said that working mothers who are struggling for money, could “work in abattoirs” for extra cash. This is the trouble with struggling working mothers – too few of them are prepared to make ends meet by strangling a pig. This would also solve the problem of lazy pigs who live off handouts of swill, rather than get off their trotters and do an honest day’s work like Peppa Pig and Miss Piggy and Pinky and Perky. So we should be grateful that our hard-working MPs do at least give up  minutes a year of their time, to go into Parliament, and vote to ensure the poor stay happy by being even poorer. title: army veteran takes life after
story: Exclusive: Army veteran takes own le after PTSD therapy axed as grieving family blame Tory cutsAlan Forcer was a lance corporal with the Coldstream Guards but suffered years of mental problems after duty in Kosovo. He was found dead in May after walking his dog in woodland near his homeAlan Forcer was  when he joined the Army Image: © Steve BainbridgeByMartyn HalleJohn Siddle:,  Nov An Army veteran died in a ­suspected suicide after the Government slashed funding for a charity that was helping him. Alan Forcer got a letter from Combat Stress saying his PTSD therapy was axed because of a cut to its budget. Alan’s ex-we Claire, , said the loss of his place on an anger ­management course sent him into a tailspin – and he was found dead four months later. Claire, mum to their son Josh, got a text from Alan which read: “DunnoI got the strength to start again.” Alan was a lance corporal with the Coldstream Guards but suffered years of mental problems after horrying duty in Kosovo.  NHS funding for Combat Stress was cut from  onwards.Alan, , got his letter in January  and was found dead in May after walking his dog in woodland near his home in Hartlepool, Co Durham. An inquest will be held next year. The charity’s letter said: “It is with great sadness that we cannot help you at this time. We recommend that you talk to your GP about finding a possible alternative service to help you.”  Claire, from Canewdon, Essex, who remained on good terms with Alan after their split in , said: “I believe Combat Stress losing its money and them having to cancel their therapy work ­contributed to him dying. “He seemed to be turning the corner in  and then their letter arrived. “It gave him a feeling of despair. I think he felt abandoned by people who understood him. “He was now being asked to speak to strangers and start all over again.”  Alan, who joined up aged , saw the bodies of civilians killed in ethnic cleansing horrors in the Balkans. He later suffered complex post-traumatic stress which went undiagnosed for years, said Claire. Through Combat Stress, Alan had been due to go on a six-week therapy course before being referred to the NHS Veterans’ Mental Health Service. Son Josh, , added: “Mum and I thought things were improving until they took the money away for his therapy. You have to be careful how you deal with vulnerable people.” Jeff Harrison, interim CEO at Combat Stress, said: “It was a very dficult decision for us to make as we wanted to be there for every veteran who needed us. “However, the cuts in funding had left us dependent on public donations and unable to provide a critical service to veterans nationwide. “We urge veterans and their families to call our -hour helpline on    or visit combatstress.org.uk.” The Ministry of Defence has ­been contacted for comment. The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter. story: Best festive sandwiches tested as we try out Christmas offerings from Waitrose to PretCosta, Starbucks, Waitrose, Tesco, Pret and Greggs are just some of the food outlets we have judged in our mission to find the best festive sandwich on the shelvesReporter Miranda Knox spent an afternoon judging the best Christmas lunches on offer Image: Tim MerryByMiranda Knox:,  Nov | commentsThe countdown to Christmas is on, which can mean only one thing – an abundance of festive sandwiches hitting the shelves. title: boy 16 begs i dont
story: Exclusive: Boy, , begs "I dont want to die" after NHS doctors insist on end-of-le careWilliam Verden, , has a rare kidney disease and needs le saving treatment to keep him alive but medics believe his complex autism means it cannot be carried out properlyAmy believes Williams autism has played a factor in the hospitals decision to stop treatment Image: NB PRESS LTDByAmy SharpeReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA distraught mum is battling to stop doctors sending her son home for what may be his last Christmas. William Verden, , made a heartbreaking plea: “I don’t want to die. My tubes keep me safe.” Doctors have ruled the teenager, diagnosed with a rare kidney disease two years ago, should no longer have le-saving treatment and receive palliative care instead. Mum Amy, , is aghast at the “death sentence” decision and is prepared to go to the High Court to keep her boy alive. Today, he was well enough to play golf – and can still hit up to  balls on a range. Amy said: “They are sending him home to die. I’ll never let it happen. “If William was in pain or bed-bound then of course I wouldn’t want him to suffer – but he has an incredible quality of le. He plays golf twice a week, I take him shopping, he plays with the local kids. We are in limbo wonderingthis will be William’s last Christmas, or whether he will even make it to thenhe has to go on palliative care.”  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter William, who also has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism, is kept alive through dialysis and without it would have “days or maybe weeks” to live, said Amy. But medics believe his complex autism means it cannot be carried out properly. Doctors treating him at Manchester Children’s Hospital were given a second opinion by an expert from Newcastle who said his kidneys are “devastated” – and a transplant is unlikely to work and carries huge risks. Amy said: “He is probably going to die from this. But he’s not ready to die now. He deserves a chance like everyone.” She fears William’s autism and ADHD have influenced the decision, as many kidney patients receive dialysis for their entire lives. William has interfered with tube lines and entry points, and at times needed restraining during dialysis.  Amy said: “It’s his disability, he’s not interfering with the line on purpose. He hated dialysis at first, then he got used to it – he just needs time. I don’t believe doctors would be advising us in this wayhe wasn’t autistic.”She and William’s dad, Will, , won’t accept Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust’s recommendation.They believe their son should continue to receive therapy and be added to the transplant waiting list. In December , a routine blood test revealed William, then , had focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.  His kidneys were ing at just %. FSGS afflicts around seven in every million people, attacking the kidneys’ filtering units, causing scarring that leads to permanent damage and, sometimes, organ failure. William was initially on steroids but by May , having reached end-stage kidney failure, he was having peritoneal dialysis via his stomach at home. It uses the lining of the abdomen to filter blood inside the body. Amy joined her son at the dialysis machine from pm until am, six days a week. She said: “At first it was horrendous, it took two hours to coax him to get on and he’d have to be occupied the whole time. He would scream and get violent at times.”  Yet William adjusted and led a “normal le”, attending his special needs school until this September, when the tube opening became infected and inflamed with peritonitis. He spent two weeks at MCH, where medics said the treatment was no longer viable. Amy said: “It was the first time they said the words ‘palliative care’.” She begged them to try hemodialysis , where blood is pumped from the body to an articial kidney machine and ed by tubes. She said: “Doctors were not keen because they knew William touched his dressings and picked at his body.” But after a meeting between health trust staff, his social worker and his parents, William had a HD line fitted on September . He began visiting the hospital three times a week for treatment but often screamed, cried and pulled dressings off. Security staff were often needed to restrain him. A consultant’s report said William “tried to disconnect himself repeatedly, putting himself at risk as well as dialysis staff” and sessions often had to be prematurely stopped, resulting in “inadequate dialysis”. William also found the fluid and diet restriction involved in treatment dficult. In the first month, he needed the lines replaced or repositioned three times. On the third occasion, on October , Amy and Will were advised that palliative care would be the best form of action. “I was at a loss for words – then I just said no,” said Amy, who lives in Newton, Lancs. She said: “Yes, there have been dficulties with HD but he’s getting used to it now and just needs more time.” Children with FSGS progressing to kidney failure have a le expectancy of around  years following the start of dialysis but can live an average of  after a transplant. It is unclearthis dfers in those who have ADHD and autism. A letter from the Clinical Ethics Committee at Manchester University Foundation Trust said “every effort” has been put in place to treat William but concludes that continuing would do “more harm [...] than good.” There is an “extremely high” likelihood that FSGS would recur in a transplanted kidney, it found. A consultant from another hospital said he “can only envisage William lurching from one crisis to another on dialysis”. Reinsertion of dialysis lines “will gradually become more dficult” and “may become impossible,” he said, adding: “With these recurrent crises I think it would be highly unlikely he will live long enough to make it to transplant on the waiting list.” Amy, also mum to Levi, , and Ruby, , said: “Since going on HD his bloods are better and so is his quality of le as he’s not tied to the machine for  hours a night. Last week I took him shopping and for lunch – then he went to respite and played pool until pm. “Every Sunday he goes golfing. The other day he walked . miles on the course.” And fun loving William has even dressed up as a chef at his school and as a security guard at hospital. If MFT and William’s parents cannot reach a resolution the courts will have to decide. Amy said: “This whole thing is a nightmare. My daughter is devastated, she cries all the time. I will never live with myselfI don’t fight for him to have this chance.” Liz Davis, of Irwin Mitchell lawyers, which is supporting William’s family, said: “All Amy wants is the best possible le and future for William. We’ll continue to support Amy and the family to ensure their voices are heard.” MFT, which manages the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital, said: “We recognise that this is a very dficult time for William and his family and we will continue to support them.” Comment MORE ON HospitalsLe expectancySocial workersTeenagersTherapyAutism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. Over a period of  hours, all five of them were ruthlessly garrotted by Ford, who killed the children with a ft rope from behind, before telling neighbours sheaposd left him. Days before the first body was found, Ford even asked a neighbourhe could store some Christmas presents at his home so the children would not find them. He reburied the decaying bodies of Sarah and Anne Marie in a field, and was arrested before he could move the others. Ford never explained why he killed them, but police speculated he had begun a sexual relationship with Sarah Jane. Ford told police: For the le of me, I do not even understand why I did what I did.  Nigel Pascoe QC, who prosecuted the case said: This was not a crime of passion but of savagery. Dad Michael, a live-in childrenaposs carer, said: I knew something was wrong as soon as I was told Lesley and the children were missing. Their deaths killed me - I was drinking very heavily to try and numb the pain. I need someone to tell me he wonapost ever come out of prison after what he did. Michael is now married to we Pauline Tranter, , and has stepchildren Robert, , and Darren, , as well as a -year-old step-daughter from a previous relationship, but has had no more biological children. He has never wished to see the man who killed his children although a prison officer told Ford had informally requested to see him years ago. He said: He could make me feel hundreds of times worse. ButI did, Iaposd want to ask why he did it.  Iaposd want to know why he felt the need to kill my children. He recently visited the childrensapos former school in Helston where the school had erected a memorial, rebuilt in recent months due to a refurb.It was the first time heaposd been, and found the strength after connecting with his daughteraposs old school pals on a recently created Facebook memorial page,He said: It had been on my mind for quite to share the story a while before I started speaking to their friends. Before then it hadnapost been the right time but now I feel ready and I have the support to do it. I have never really known how. After speaking to their friends and visiting the childrenaposs school, and after  years, I felt ready.  Ford will not be eligible for release until . However, in some cases a apospre-tarf reviewapos can be carried out two years before a prisoner reaches their minimum sentence, in which an assessment is made over whether they will be suitable for release once they have reached their tarf. The Secretary of State considers such cases and then makes a referral to the Parole Board. Michael said: For years Iaposve been asked to speak out about what happened, but I wasnapost ready. Now he could be out in a few years, itaposs the right time to start talking. If he is ever released, nobody will be safe - I believe he would kill again. It still kills me now - and the thought that he could soon be out after what he did makes me more and more angry. That man deserves to suffer le inside for what he has done - he ended five lives. I feel like Iaposm the one suffering a le sentence after what he did to my family. The petition, which has now been signed more than , times, reads: We have to live with what he did for the rest of our lives and feel that he should never be released. The effect their deaths had on anyone that knew them was catastrophic - from family to all their school friends. In the eyes of the law familial crime is not judged the same as stranger killing. In my opinion it’s worse as the person who you loved and trusted the most commits the ultimate betrayal. I hope you will all sign this petition to ensure that Lee Ford stays in prison for the rest of his natural le. Someone that planned and executed the murder of five people and then covered it up is beyond words. title: family find dream come true
story: Family find dream come true message in bottle written by school kids in The Hibberts spotted the plastic bottle caught in branches while walking along the River Clwyd in North Wales and initially picked it up to throw it away before seeing the message inside.Cat Hibbert holds up the plastic bottle containing the letter from  Image: Cat HibbertByAnnie Owen:,  Nov | commentsA bottle containing a message written by school children  years ago has been found in a river in North Wales. The remarkable discovery was made by a family who were walking along the banks of the River Clwyd in Denbigshire. The Hibbert family saw something caught in branches at the rivers edge. Initially, they thought the plastic bottle was rubbish and picked it up to throw it away but then spotted what looked like a note inside, the Daily Post reports. Cat Hibbert said: We were so excited when we saw the piece of paper and realised there could be a message inside because this kind of thing only happens in books or films. Itaposs like a childaposs dream come true and my children couldnapost wait to open it up and see what was inside.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Steffan Hibbert, , Sophie Birkett, , Rowan Hibbert, , and Isabel Birkett, , helped find the bottle. But the family had to wait until they got home to fish out the letter, which had been jammed inside the bottle for more than  years.Inside they found an astonishing letter written by school children from Ysgol Y Llys in Prestatyn, dated December , .Mrs Hibbert said: As soon as I read the letter I knew we had happened across something very special. To think that it was written by school children all those years ago is incredible. The mum-of-two said she was surprised that the letter, written in English on one side and Welsh on the other, was so well preserved after more than three decades. The message said: Dear finder, We standard three and four have been following the afon Clwyd [the river]. We dropped this bottle in forest Clocaenog. Would you be kind enough to send a letter or phone the number  to tell you found it. Thank you, on behalf of the children in standard  + .  Do you know the children who sent this message  Email us at webnews@mirrorAside from the date at the top, there are some other clues that the letter wasnapost written recently. The phone number in the letter is only four digits long- phone numbers in the UK began to change to five or six digits in the s following a number shortage. The children also wrote that they were in standard three and four, which is believed to be year five and six today. The plastic bottle was found at the edge of the River Clwyd in Melin y Wig, which is only around six miles from Clocaenog Forest where it is believed to have started its journey almost  years ago. Mrs Hibbert said the discovery has left her wondering where the bottle has been for all of this time and said sons Rowan and Steffan are aposdesperateapos to get in touch with the school pupils who left the bottle all those years ago. She said: I posted it on social media to try and find anyone that may have been involved at the time. It would be wonderful to find out more about the story and would be great for children at the school now to get involved and learn about the history. story: Exclusive: Liverpool police probe car full of suspicious men seen before hospital bombingCCTV specialists have been at Liverpool Womens Hospital for three days after it emerged that bomber Emad Al Swealmeen could visited the night before the botched attackThe taxi engulfed in fire outside Liverpool Womens HospitalByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsCounter terror police are probing a theory that the Liverpool bomber scoped out the maternity hospital where he struck less than a day before the blast. Insiders say CCTV experts are trawling footage from the days before last Sunday’s attack to seeEmad Al Swealmeen was caught on film. Footage is believed to show a blue Ford Fiesta pulling up at Liverpool Women’s Hospital at around .pm on Saturday –  hours before the blast – and staying for around five minutes. The Sunday Mirror understands a member of staff raised the alarm about the car, which is thought to have been carrying five young men. An insider said: “CCTV specialists were at the hospital for three days. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter “They are investigating whether the bomber scoped out the hospital because he has been buying parts since April. They wanted to know whether he had been in the hospital or not. “A blue Fiesta pulled up the night before and it had five men in it. They were acting suspiciously. It stayed for six minutes. They didn’t get out at all. “You can’t make out who the men were from the CCTV. It could have been him and his mates – we just don’t know.” Al Swealmeen, , drew up outside the hospital in a taxi at .am last Sunday. His homemade bomb went off seconds later. Driver David Perry, , miraculou sly escaped before his cab burst into flames. He’s now being cared for at home by we Rachel.  It was originally thought Al Swealmeen planned to detonate his homemade bomb at a nearby Remembrance Day parade. But eyewitnesses insist David, who temporarily lost his hearing, said his passenger had always intended to go to the hospital. One said: “The driver looked in the back just before the bomb went off. He said he saw a red flashing light and the bomber rustling around in his jacket. He heard vibrations and stuff. “As soon as the bomb went off, the back left passenger door blew open and the taxi driver’s door opened.”  A string of hospital staff and passersby helped David and tried to put out the fire before emergency services arrived. A witness said: “The driver wanted to go to the car to get his phone but the car was ablaze. He said, ‘I want my we, I can’t hear.’ His eyes were wide open. “It’s amazing he got out alive. I think the seat took most of the impact. But he didn’t have a Covid screen in place like people have said – which makes it even more incredible he survived.” Security guard Will Cowan,  charged towards the burning car as his horried mum Christine watched but it was too well alight for him to help. Christine had been working in the hospital cafe when the blast happened. Our witness said: “Because Will dealt with it, she was crying her eyes out saying, ‘I thought you were going to die’.” Will’s car was one of two destroyed by the blast. Tonight, he said he didn’t want to speak about the attack. Traumatised staff have been offered counselling. The insider said: “Everyone has been on edge. People have been shaking. The atmosphere is horrible.” And new mums being cared for when the bomb went off have called in to report physical and mental issues. Our source said: “New mums are saying they are having problems.“One said she can’t leave the house, she’s having headaches and can’t hear.Assistant Chief Constable Russ Jackson, Head of Counter Terrorism Police North West, said on Friday his investigation was making “signicant progress” after speaking to Al Swealmeen’s brother. He said: “This has given us an insight into his early years and an understanding of Al Swealmeen’s le and his recent state of mind.” The bomb had ball bearings attached, which would have acted as shrapnel. Mr Jackson added: “Had it detonated in dferent circumstances it would have caused signicant injury or death. “We still do not know why the device exploded when it did, but we are not discounting it being unintentional. “It is a possibility movement of the vehicle or its stopping caused ignition.” Comment MORE ON CCTVHospitalsTerrorismCCTV footageSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: holiday passenger jet near miss
story: Holiday passenger jet in near miss with ‘five purple balloons at ,ft’The purple balloons, which were tied together, “passed just under the right wing” of the B jet which is believed to have been a Jet flight from Ibiza to NewcastleThe close call happened as the plane carrying up to  passengers was flying at mph Image: NurPhoto via Getty ImagesByAdam AspinallNews reporter:,  Nov | commentsA pilot was left “chuckling” in his ­cockpit after almost hitting five balloons at ,ft, a report has revealed.The purple balloons, which were tied together, “passed just under the right wing” of the Boeing  jet which is believed to have been a Jet flight from Ibiza to Newcastle.The close call happened as the plane carrying up to  passengers was flying at mph just north of Chester-le-Street, County Durham, on its descent on August  this year. A report by the UK Airprox Board which investigates near misses rated it at as a Category A incident where there was a serious risk of collision. It said that the pilot reported the incident to air traffic controllers, transmitting “just a report of a near miss with about  or  balloons, they just nearly hit us ”. The report said the incident “was acknowledged and as no other aircraft were in the vicinity no further action was taken”. Do you have a story  Email webnews@mirror Flight tracker records identied the plane involved as the Jet flight. The airline has been approached for comment. In a separate incident, an airliner carrying up to  passengers came close to hitting a child’s large helium balloon as it came in to land at Manchester airport. The easyJet pilots spotted the balloon soaring into the air in front of them when they were flying at around mph and just seconds from touching down. The UKAB report said the pilots of the A jet initially thought the object was a drone until they got closer and realised it was a helium balloon. The pilots thought there was “a potential of damage” to an engine of their jetthey abandoned their landing with only seconds to go. An easyJet spokesperson said: “We are aware of the issue and reported the event to the relevant authorities and supported the investigation in line with our safety procedures. “At no point was the safety of those onboard compromised. The safety and wellbeing of passengers and crew is always easyJet’s highest priority.” It is highly unlikely balloons could take down a passenger jet but they could certainly cause problems. In  a bundle of helium balloons were believed to have played a role in the crash of a small twin engine plane in Calornia in which the pilot lost his le. Aviation investigators discovered pieces of balloons scattered near the crash site and concluded they may have been flying too low. news uk-news i-never-give-up-search-"Katrice Lees father talks about day of her disappearanceByNazrin WilkinsonPhil CardySenior reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Heartbroken Richard Lee stands at the spot where his daughter vanished on her second birthday  years ago, still clinging to the hope he might one day find her. He is haunted by a mixture of grief and despair – and burning anger at a botched Army investigation into little Katrice’s disappearance from a garrison NAAFI store while shopping with her mum. That fury was only deepened by -year-old Richard’s last meeting with the Royal Military Police who revealed FIFTEEN sex offenders were in the area on the day that shattered his le – before telling him they would only reopen the search for hernew evidence came to light. “To find that out,  years after the event,” he says. “I sat in a room with them and they showed me silhouette pictures of them.  “I know  sex offenders could cover a wide range of offences. All I’ve ever wanted is truth and honesty, but I’ve not received that.” His former MP, who was with him at the meeting last December, was also flabbergasted at the RMP’s revelation. Now a retired Sgt Major, Richard, of Hartlepool, has made an emotionalto the village of Schloss Neuhaus, near Paderborn, Germany, to the place where his daughter was last seen – to “stir the embers” and keep the case fresh in people’s memories. It was November , , and Katrice, wearing red wellies and a purple coat, was standing with mum Sharon and aunt Wendy by the checkout at the store – now the site of a conference hall – near her dad’s Army base.  Sharon realised she had forgotten crisps for her birthday party and asked Wendy to watch the tot, but when she ed less than a minute later, Katrice was gone. Wendy told her she had run after her, and she thought they were together. Richard, who had driven them to the store – as big as a medium-sized Tesco – was waiting by his car. Forty years on, he looks around him, recalling the day his le stopped. “When they didn’t come out I went in. Sharon and her sister were in the manager’s office in tears. She told me, ‘Katrice is missing’. I grabbed some of my men and searched the area. “Then the Royal Military Police arrived. Those first few hours were critical – the ‘golden hours’ – but they didn’t even do the simple things like shut the shop and take names and addresses of everyone in there.  “They didn’t interview the women on the tills for six weeks. They questioned me and Sharon in separate rooms. They asked her ‘does Katrice like ducks ’. What two-year-old child doesn’t  In my mind that shows they’d made their mind up without investigating anything properly. “They assumed she’d fallen into the River Alme around  yards away. But it was busy around there. “The college had an open day and the garrison had just ed from a three-week exercise. There were hundreds of people around. Someone would have seen a toddler walking towards the river. Richard, who served in the th th King’s Royal Hussars for  years, firmly believes she was taken. And he has been clinging to hope for four decades.  “I don’t believe she went near the water. I believe she was abducted and is out there somewhere,” he says. “Someone has scooped her up, told her, ‘Let’s look for Mummy and Daddy’ to calm her – and then taken her. “She doesn’t know who she really is – but someone out there does. I will never give up looking for her. No parent would ever give up on their child. Over the years I’ve been to some dark places in my mind. And part of that is coming back here again. “It’s like walking back into any parent’s worst nightmare. I’m living that nightmare. There’s no closure. “I didn’t come here for all the agony and pain this place brings me. I’m here because Katrice is constantly on my mind and in my heart. “I passionately believe Katrice is out there. Hope never dies.”  And neither does Richard’s anger over the RMP investigation which has even astounded his former MP Mike Hill, who was with him at the meeting where the  sex offenders “in the area” at the time were mentioned. He said: “My impression was that it was around the vicinity of the NAAFI. That’s what went into my mind. It beggared belief. There were so many unanswered questions. They didn’t fill in the details. It was quite a deflating meeting for Richard, but I think after all these years he’d anticipated that. What he has been through is just horrendous.” In , a search along the banks of the Alme found bone fragments. Richard said Sharon, now his ex-we, and their older daughter, Natasha, , were “on tenterhooks” waiting for news – only for the RMP to post on social media that they were horse bones. He said: “They did that before informing the family. That shows how we’ve been treated.”  Earlier this month Boris Johnson agreed to meet Richard “father to father” to discuss the case, although a date has yet to be set. Richard said: “I want to speak to him about the treatment of my family.“I’d like to ask why the case has been scaled back  Every missing child needs to be treated equally.” The RMP has previously apologised for failings in its investigation, which included delays in interviewing key witnesses and not releasing a photofit of a suspect for  years. The MOD said: “A review of the investigation in  did not identy any new lines of inquiry. “The Lee family were briefed in person on its outcome and the decision to end active investigations.” Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Ministry of DefenceBritish ArmyMilitary PoliceBoris JohnsonMissing personsSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: night time toilet habit could
story: Night time toilet habit could be sign of aggressive cancer, warn medicsNocturia is a condition that causes you to wake up during the night to urinate, according to the Cleveland Clinic - and could be a sign of prostate cancerProstate cancer is the second-most common form of disease among men after skin cancer Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA toilet break at night could be a sign of an aggressive cancer, medical experts have warned. If you have a sudden or increased need to urinate throughout the night it could be a sign of prostate cancer. Nocturia is a condition that causes you to wake up during the night to urinate, according to the Cleveland Clinic. Severe nocturia has been found in  per cent of prostate cancer cases as a side effect of radiation treatment, studies have shown.The condition can also result from a tumour that is growing in size and pushing against the urethra, Thereports.  The Cleveland Clinic says: This can be thought of as nocturnal urinary frequency - having to urinate more often at night. Nocturnia typically occurs in the later stages of the disease, meaning treatments must start right away.The NHS notes that: “Prostate cancer does not usually cause any symptoms until the cancer has grown large enough to put pressure on the tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the penis. Symptoms of prostate cancer can include needing to pee more frequently, often during the night. Early prostate cancer can be dficult to detect due to the lack of obvious symptoms. According to Prostate Cancer UK,you are aged  or over, your father or brother has had the disease, or you are black, you should speak to your GP. The drop in cancer screening rates during the Covid- could have repercussions for cancer survival in the coming years.There is overwhelming evidence that diet is a strong determinant of cancer.There is growing evidence that a plant-based diet may lower the risk of disease and slow its spread.Those who eat more fruits, vegetables, legumes and fish are less likely to see their cancer grow to the point of needing treatment, researchers have determined.These foods contain naturally occurring plant compounds, known as carotenoids, which could protect the body against DNA damage.Red-coloured fruits are particularly apt at protecting the body against cancer, due to their lycopene content, studies have found.Eating canned tomatoes slashed the risk of prostate cancer by  per cent in a  study published in Cancer Causes and Control. Prostate cancer is the second-most common form of disease among men after skin cancer. The disease is often labelled aggressive for its ability to spread quickly to neighbouring lymph nodes and organsleft untreated. Doctor Bradley McGregor, an oncologist with the Hard-affiliated Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, said: The same dietary habits that can lower your risk of prostate cancer can have a similar effect to perhaps slowing its spread. So, no matter where you are in terms of prostate cancer - from monitoring PSA levels to treating a diagnosis - take the opportunity now to get serious about your diet. marrying an Egyptian toyboy  years her junior has been reunited with him after a year-long wait for him to get his visa. But despite her previous frank revelations about their sex le Iris Mohamady, previously Jones, , said she and Mohamed, , simply toasted his arrival in the UK on Friday with “a cup of tea”. The retired care worker told the Sunday Mirror: “We didn’t celebrate – we are just together and that’s celebration enough. “We just had a cup of tea together. title: trophy hunters face seven years
story: Trophy hunters face seven years jail as stars urge support for new lawLabour MP John Spellar’s plan is supported by celebrities and across the political ide, including by Tory MPs. It would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offenceThe new bill would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offence Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByChris McLaughlinPolitical reporter:,  Nov | commentsHunters smuggling in big game trophies face seven years’ jail under a planned new law. And all owners of hunting trophies – such as lion skins, tusks, antlers, heads and other macabre souvenirs – would have to register or face jail.The changes, proposed in a Bill, come after legislation promised by PM Boris Johnson two years ago has failed to appear.Labour MP John Spellar’s plan is supported by celebrities and across the political ide, including by Tory MPs.Hunters can import trophies of animals, including polar bears and reindeer, ­under a limited number of Government licences.The Hunting TrophyBill would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offence, with culprits facing up to seven years in jail.  It would bring trophy smuggling into line with laws covering the import of ivory from elephants and rhino. Mr Spellar said: “It’s time for action, not words. We need to make sure that these sick imports are stopped and the only way to do that is to make it a crime.” Actress Dame Judi Dench said the Government should back the Bill to show its “determination to ban animals being senselessly slaughtered for souvenirs.”  Downton Abbey star Peter Egan said: “Wildle can’t wait any more. “Every year that goes by without this ban in place means ­hundreds more animals are killed just for kicks.” The private members’ bill is likely to need Government support to become law. Spoof of evil offer Campaigners have produced spoof ads to shame hunters and their “sport” of shooting animals for fun. The ads for “Trophy Hunting Holidays” mock real offers marketed by the trophy hunting industry. Huge posters from the -second social media parody launched today will be circling Parliament from tomorrow. Voiced by Peter Egan and Vikings actor Richard Ashton, it offers “hot new deals” such as two-for-one lion kills, cheetah hunts for £,, giraffes for £, and elephants for £,. Campaign Against Trophy Hunting’s Eduardo Goncalves said: “It’s funny in a dark way but the idea is to show just how grotesque and twisted the industry is.” Comment MORE ON Peter EganJohn SpellarBoris JohnsonJudi DenchDownton AbbeyPolar bearsPoliticsAnimalsChristmas partySunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uk gritter road salt shortage
story: UK gritter and road salt shortage could make roads icy death traps as temperatures fallThere are fears that there are not enough employees to remove snow from the street and keep motorists safe. Officials have also warned of a shortage of road salt compared to previous wintersA shortage of HGV drivers could have an impact on road safety, officials have warned Image: PA Archive Press Association ImagesByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | commentsThe UK is facing a shortage of gritters and road salt, which could make roads dangerous as temperatures are set to plunge around the country.While forecasters have warned Brits to prepare for freezing weather conditions in the coming weeks, there are fears that there are not enough employees to remove snow from the street and keep motorists safe. The issue is linked to a wider shortage of HGV drivers, which has seen vacancies jump by nearly a third across the UK compared to pre-pandemic levels.Highways chiefs are warning that a lack of staff to spread salt on the roads could cause traffic chaos this winter. Do you have a story  Email webnews@mirror. Officials also said that there is less grit in stock than in recent winters, with transport bosses in Scotland saying there are , fewer tonnes of salt in stock than last year.The Local Government Association said the driver shortage could mean gritting runs are axed, the Daily Star reports.Spokesman Cllr David Renard said: Some councils may find gritting services are affected in the same way as some waste collection services have been impacted.  Meanwhile, authorities in Hampshire said they are training new drivers to ensure we can maintain our winter service when demand peaks. Wrexham Council said it was monitoring the situation very closely.It comes as forecasters warned the UK can expect sub-zero temperatures from tomorrow, with lows of -C likely by the end of November.Forecasters at MetDesk said: A big change is shown for next week, with Arctic winds, plummeting temperatures and snow for some.The Met Office warned of heavy snowfall in the north of the UK on Monday, with the cold blast predicted to reach the south by Wednesday night.Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: I couldnapost imagine a better weather pattern for cold weather fans, with forecast models showing a northerly straight from the Arctic next week. title: woman abandoned baby reunites mum
story: Woman abandoned as baby reunites with mum  years later but only as friendsAnne Harrison, , was left at St Cross Hospital in Rugby in Warcs. after her mum, who came from Barbados, fell pregnant and was unable to look after her - after years of searching she was finally able to find herAnne Harrison finally met up with her mother but says she still wont acknowledge her as her daughter Image: CoventryLive  WSByLata YedroudjAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA woman who was abandoned at a hospital as a baby reunited with her mum  years later. Anne Harrison, , was left at St Cross Hospital in Rugby in Warcs. after her mum, who came from Barbados, fell pregnant and was unable to look after her.The baby was placed in an orphanage and later a white couple offered to foster her, CoventryLive reports.Anne soon realised she was dferent in school because of her skin colour and was taunted and bullied by her peers. She said: It wasnapost until I started going to school that I realised I was dferent.  I had dferent skin and I was taunted and teased and children called me bad names. My white foster carers didnapost treat me dferently to any member of the family. They used to tell me to ignore the kids at school, but within the family, I was treated as one of them. Anneaposs foster parents emigrated to Australia when she was nine and she was moved to a childrenaposs home. At , Anne received the shocking news that she had a younger brother living in a separate childrenaposs home.  She said: When I was about  or , the authorities were informed by the police that my mum likely had a breakdown and was at the hospital. She told the police officers that she had a son who lived in Berkshire at the time, and she had a daughter as well, which was me. We were both in dferent childrenaposs homes. Fortunately, weaposre both very close and we see each other on a regular basis. Anne started to look for her mum when she was . Anneaposs mother would write letters to her but refused to meet her children in person. One day, Anne made a trip to London to seeher mother was at one of the old addresses she was writing from - but she wasnapost there. Anne decided to focus on her career but still kept searching for her mother. That same year, when Anne was  she began working as a police cadet for Warwickshire Police and left the childrenaposs home to live in provided accommodation by the police force.  At , Anne was a working police officer and after three years in the force, she decided to leave to become a social worker starting in Stratford, East London and then moved to Coventry. She said: When I first came to Coventry I would very rarely see another black person. I was so confused about how to look after my hair, how to deal with my skin, were there any other people who looked like me. I was brought up in a white household, my foster parents were white.  The childrenaposs home was predominantly white, being in the police force was predominantly white. I was one of the first black police cadets in Warwickshire. In her late s, Anne was able to locate her mum. She agreed to meet Anne and they set up a date to see each other for the first time. Anne says she was overwhelmed when she met her mother for the first time. Anne said: I was a little overwhelmed. It was like looking at a mirror of myself, but it was emotional.  I knew that she had been crying before we met. She still would not acknowledge me as her daughter, she kept saying we were meeting as friends. There was still that barrier and it still exists today. Anne has met her mother at least eight times over the years - but it was always at a distance. She added I know very little about her or what she chooses to tell me. A little bit comes out each time we meet. Itaposs little steps, but itaposs very much a distant relationship and I had to accept that this is as far as it goes. Anne and her brother now live in dferent cities but are very close and see each other regularly.Anne has released her biography, aposCall Me Auntieapos, about her le in care and the search for her mother available to purchase here. title: woman says hermes ruined christmas
story: Woman says Hermes has ruined her Christmas after disgusting delivery of gtNicola Rooney, , claims Hermes left her husbands surprise present on their doorstep in Birkenhead, Merseyside - a site which countless people walk past each dayNicola Rooney, , has slammed Hermes after a delivery of a gt on her doorstep in Birkenhead, Merseyside went missingByRebecca KoncienzcyRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov  A woman says Hermes has ruined Christmas for her husband after a disgusting delivery. Nicola Rooney, , from Birkenhead, Merseyside, had been waiting  days for a Remington shaver to arrive - a surprise gt for her partner Tank, .As the days went on and the parcel didnapost appear, she contacted the online retailer, Studio, to ask about the hold up.She told the Liverpool Echo : I ordered a £ Remington shaver for my husband and was wondering where it was, because it doesnapost take  days to get here.When I contacted Studio they said it had been delivered. I checked with Hermes and they had a picture of it just on the doorstep. I never received this, it was clear from the picture I didnapost receive it. Nicolaapos says she was disgusted because it was obvious that they left it while knowing no one was there to sign for it. She said: It is disgusting. You can clearly see in the picture no one was there to take the parcel, they usually have photos of a delivery showing the door open, but this is obviously closed. It is really frustrating because we live on the corner and everyone can just see it. It has completely ruined Christmas for him [Tank] because there is no surprise. Nicola says Studio agreed to refund the money and send a new shaver. She added: It is the principle of the matter. I have seen similar things like this happen to others. Something needs to be done, Hermes has a duty of care, they should be named and shamed. I am lucky, it wasnapost massively valuable and I have had a refund. But it could have been something very expensive so to just dump it is unacceptable, they are not taking any pride in this. A spokesperson for Hermes said: We have been in contact with Ms Rooney to apologise for any inconvenience and provide her with a full refund so that she can order another shaver in time for Christmas. This is a very busy time of year and our local couriers are working hard to deliver, so we would ask that people try to be at home when expecting a delivery or choose an alternative service such as deliver to a neighbour or ParcelShop where available. Anyone experiencing delivery issues should contact their retailer or seller in the first instance, who will in turn contact Hermesrequired. title: woman stays absolutely filthy hotel
story: Woman stays in absolutely filthy hotel with hole in wall and cracked windowsLeanne booked the Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool for her sister Libby and her partner as a surprise after working through the pandemic as a care worker - and says they were moved to another room that was just as badA woman has blasted the rooms at The Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool Image: Andrew Teebay Liverpool EchoByAaliyah RuggAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman who booked a surprise hotel stay for her sister and partner has been left horried at the room she was given.Leanne, who did not want her surname to be published, booked the Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool for her sister Libby and her partner for a surprise after working through the pandemic, the Liverpool ECHO reports. She says the roomaposs window was cracked and there was a hole in the ceiling with a bin underneath. Leanne told the ECHO: Me and my little sister have both worked right the way through the pandemic. She works days and I work nights and sheaposs been helping me look after my little boy. So to say thank you I wanted to book her and her partner a little getaway.  We live in Norfolk now but are from Liverpool and have family here so I thought it would be nice for them to come back to our home city. Originally I was going to book the Dolby hotel but I thought it would be out the way, so I changed my mind and booked the Adelphi instead because itaposs right in town and everything is close. She arrived on Monday and was put in one room but the window was all cracked and there was a hole in the ceiling with a bin under it. The bin was covered with water as though there had been a leak and was also covered with rubbish.  In the bathroom, the towel rail was off the wall and just sat on the floor. They went to complain and they were given another room which was smaller but just as bad. After complaining about the state of the second room, the couple were given a new room. Leanne added: The window was all cracked and the bed linen was so dirty. This was all on the first day and she was put in another room. I FaceTimed her that night and she didnapost look happy at all. Outside the room, there were holes in the ceiling.  I rang the hotel myself and the sht manager said he would sort another room out. They were taken to another floor and on the corridor, there were care packages left outside of doors which made her panic people were quarantining. The manager said thataposs just how they would do things now after Covid. Another thing they do because of Covid is use paper cups. So my sister went down to get a paper cup and was given one with a lid on.  When she got back to her room she took the lid off to use it and it was absolutely filthy. It was f*****g disgusting, just minging. She then went back to the main desk for a clean one and they apologised and said it must have gotten mixed up. How can it get mixed up when itaposs a paper cup and should be thrown straight in the bin. It looked like someone had just had soup out of it. Leanne says that despite several attempts to contact Britannia Hotels, who own the Adelphi Hotel, she has had no response to complaints made. She said: What was meant to be five nice, peaceful days away were just horric. It used to be a good hotel. Iaposve since been looking at the reviews and they all say what my sister went through. Itaposs disgusting. Thecontacted Britannia Hotels for a comment.
